awd_titl_txt: Nanoconfinement, nanofluidics, new phases and their transitions for superfluid 3He
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Abstract
The pace of research and development is accelerating. Our everyday devices are ever more capable, cheaper, and faster. Most of these consumer items' inbuilt technology exists because of fundamental advances in condensed matter research. Future advances will happen because of curiosity driven exploration of new regimes presently accessible only in a laboratory environment. The research to be conducted in this program will examine the special properties of superfluid 3He when confined in precisely defined structures less than a thousandth of a millimeter tall, marking the transition from bulk three-dimensional behavior to a new two-dimensional regime. Undergraduate students and Ph.D students will design and fabricate these structures opening up a new area of quantum nano-fluidics.  The surfaces will have to have a well-defined smoothness - and the surface coating (with pure helium 4 or helium 3 under a magnetic field) should alter the types of superfluid states ("phases") that emerge. These phases should show a property "chirality" that should have properties like a spinning top. Further, the conversion from one state to another ("phase transition") should reveal whether models of the early universe (important for our understanding of the evolution of the universe) can be tested in the laboratory. Past graduate students and undergraduates working with this research group have gone on to productive careers in academia, high-technology industries and the financial sector, and the planned research will prepare a new generation of students for challenging careers. The size range where the system transforms from a nearly three-dimensional material to a more two-dimensional system will be revealed by new phases. These new phases should exhibit novel characteristics such as highly conducting "edge states" that are scientifically "exciting" and that could, in the future form the basis of new types of devices for metrology and computation. 

Technical abstract:
Superfluid 3He can inform research activity that extends across many fields in Physics. The project combines nanofluidics (intricate and precisely fabricated cavities with sizes tuned to the scale of the superfluid's coherence length) with low temperature physics, to expose new size effects. The experimental activity will probe excitations using transport (superfluid density and heat conductivity) as well as a novel nanoscale ultra-fine wire to act as a local thermometer or spectrometer. Researchers expect that entirely new p-wave superfluid states can be stabilized by such confinement and the balance between the superfluid ground state that preserves (3He-B) or breaks (3He-A) time reversal symmetry will also be affected by confinement. By measuring the phase diagram of confined 3He both with and without an applied magnetic field, details of the pressure and temperature dependence of the strong coupling strength will be mapped out allowing for more reliable prediction of the phase diagrams of 3He under confinement.  Confinement will also provide the means to study the surface/edge excitations emerging as a result of bulk/edge correspondence. Furthermore this research activity will provide a new example of "cosmology in the laboratory". Studies of the first-order transition between the confined A and B phases, radically different from nucleation in bulk, will potentially provide a model of processes during the inflationary epoch of the early universe. New geometries will explore the physics of quantum transport across single and multiple interfaces. By combining low temperatures and nano fabrication, graduate students and undergraduates will be exposed to the exciting training ground that has prepared scientists for lead roles in academia and high-technology industries. Eventually, the new superfluids that emerge under confinement might be of interest in quantum computation.

por.por_cntn:
The project made essential contributions to science and technology by demonstrating pathways to combining nanoscale fabrication and ultralow temperature physics. We successfully demonstrated both ?m tall by cm x cm area) nanofabricated cavities that were feature free (had no support pillars) and also fully supported cavities that showed minimal distortion under pressure. These structures enabled the observation of unique spatially modulated structures in the superfluid.

We used a 1.1 ?m tall channel to confine 3He and link between two chambers. The small height of the channel and its lateral and longitudinal dimensions made for a thermally restrictive pathway allowing the thermal conduction of confined normal and superfluid 3He to be measured. The conduction in the normal liquid showed unexpeceted size and temperature dependence. In the superfluid unexpectedly long lived excitations were observed. 

On the other hand, the nucleation of the more stable phase (the B phase) at low temperature remains a mystery. The understanding of how this phase nucleates a seed and then displaces the less favored phase (A phase)  is not yet at hand. We found that transitions from the A to B phase exhibited varying degrees of supercooling (persistence beyond the point of actual stability) and fell on a line that was detatched from the line of actual stability where the A and B phases have equal energies. When cooled under different conditions, the transition did not happen at the temperature and pressure cordinates mapped under constant pressure cooling, but displayed a path dependence. The dynamics of this transformation (that is thought to have parallels with the evolution of the early universe) is worthy of pursuit. Further, the observation of the A phase nucleation even below its region of stability implies that metastable phases may be nucleated by growth from nanofabricated structures that take advantage of symmetry breaking to promote phases that are not observed in the bulk. This work was published in Physical Review Letters .

We demonstrated the compatibility of the glass-silicon and all-silicon cell construction for low temperature studies using magnetic resonance techniques using sensitive superconducting detectors.

Magnetic resonance experiments in the UK on cells fabricated at Cornell showed evidence for a ?polka-dot? state that was unanticipated but related to the ?stripe state?. These experiments demonstrate that although bulk 3He is very well understood, confined 3He and its interaction with even pristine surfaces is still new territory. Thus we believe that insights gained from our research on the influence of disorder and surfaces will have significance for the understanding of the behavior of exotically paired electron systems where exerting such control is difficult.    

The broader impacts of the research were numerous. We advanced the state of the art significantly in terms of small magnetic signal detection,  large aspect ratio structures and surface preparation for nanofluidic devices. Our students and postdocs have benefited from international collaborations with Royal Holloway in the UK. The grant resulted in several high profile publications, contributing to the scientific literature and adding to the knowledge base.  The lead  post doc (Dmytro Lotnyk) is now a high level programmer in Slovakia (EU), and a second post doc is now a researcher at the Technion in Israel. An undergrad student is now at Cornell pursuing the Thesis option for his bachelors degree and two other students are pursuing their PhD at respected institutions. As part of our continuing outreach we work with Cryomech Inc in Syracuse NY to refine laboratory scale liquefiers in the US and also exported worldwide.  Thus the program contributed to the scientific infrastructure through education and training of personnel, additions to the scientific literature, encouragement of the pursuit of STEM literacy, through applications of current technologyand for future advances where nanotechnology and flow will be utilized.
